Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Collaborative Research: Hybrid perovskite inspired pathways towards green and stable ionic PV absorbers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Shengbai Zhang / Hao Zeng
Proposal Number: 1510948 / 1510121

The sun represents the most abundant potential source of sustainable energy on earth. Solar cells for producing electricity require materials that absorb the sun's energy and convert its photons to electrons, a process called photovoltaics. Recently, materials based on inorganic-organic halide perovskite materials have achieved promising solar energy power conversion efficiency, and can be made from earth-abundant elements using low-cost, solution based processing methods. However, these perovskite materials contain lead, which is toxic, and degrade in the presence of moisture, which prevents their commercial use. To address these limitations, this project will develop and study the performance of a new class of perovskite materials which do not contain lead and are stable in moisture. This project will also provide educational and outreach opportunities, including the development of a student-designed nanotechnology display as part of the permanent Physics and Art exhibit at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, as well as development of various hands-on solar cell kits for K-12 students in the Buffalo area public schools.

Photovoltaic (PV) materials based on inorganic-organic halide perovskites have achieved power conversion efficiencies of nearly 18%, which are now comparable to CIGS and CdTe thing film solar PV materials. However, current inorganic-organic halide perovskite materials contain lead and are unstable in moisture. The overall goal of this research is to design and synthesize new ionic photovoltaic absorber materials based on non-halide perovskites that eliminate the use of lead and are stable in moisture. The proposed research has two objectives. The first objective is to understand the physics and chemistry of organic-inorganic halide perovskite materials that determine their power conversion efficiency and photo-induced degradation in water. Based on the fundamental understanding obtained under the first objective, the second objective is to design, synthesize, and characterize the photophysics of new ionic PV absorbers based on the non-halide chalcogenide perovskites which do not contain lead, as well as molecularly doped CuxS compounds proposed by a materials-by-design approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a collaborative proposal, with PIs Yiyang Sun and Shengbai Zhang from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, to conduct joint research on the development of chalcogenide perovskite solar absorber materials. Inspired by the organometallic perovskites, the proposed research here pursues a new direction in this field by developing ionic PV absorbers, which deviate from the traditional PV materials based on the covalent materials. Using molecules as elements to design crystalline materials overcomes the limitation of the Periodic Table of being discrete and containing only finite elements. The specific objectives are:  

1) To synthesize chalcogenide perovskite powder materials, focusing on BaZrS3.

2) To explore cation and anion alloying as an effective approach to tune the band gap.

3) To explore methods for thin film deposition suitable for device fabrication.

4) To characterize the structural, optical and carrier transport properties.

5) To explore other types of chalcogenide perovskites and their physical properties.

The major outcomes of the proposed work are: (a) we synthesized prototypical chalcogenide perovskite BaZrS3 polycrystalline powder samples, and verified theoretical predicted band gap value and strong light absorption; (b) we also synthesized other types of chalcogenide perovskites such as CaZrS3, SrTiS3 and SrZrS3, which possess different structures and band gap values; (c) by cation and anion alloying, we are able to systematically tune the band gap from 1.5 to 3.2 eV; (d) we further theoretically and experimentally investigated the stability of BaZrS3 using temperature and pressure dependent Raman spectroscopy; (e) recently we fabricated BaZrS3 thin film with exceptionally strong light absorption (higher than most conventional semiconductors), good carrier mobility and demonstrated shallow donor defect levels resulting from S vacancies.

 

Broader Impacts: The chalcogenide perovskites developed here not only provide new candidate materials for PV applications, but also they considerably enrich the materials database for applications currently dominated by oxide perovskites. Two graduate students obtained their Ph.D. degrees supported partially by this grant. Five undergraduate students participated in the research project, with three from underrepresented groups. One student won the Fulbright scholarship and another is the winner of the SUNY Chancellor?s Award for Student Excellence. This funded research has led to about 12 publications. They have been cited extensively. Two invited talks have been given, including one in the 2018 MRS Spring meetings, and one in Nature conference on Flexible electronics in 2016. We also organized the 2017 New York State Section of the APS Spring meeting, with the theme on renewable energy.
